answers: "Four trapezoidal bars aligned on a rectangular base" may not be instantly recognizable. Put that setup in chocolate form, however, and many people would be able to distinguish it as a KitKat. Even if that's the case, the European Union's highest court just ruled that the shape of the sweet treat isn't unique enough to merit trademark protection, meaning other confectioners can potentially produce KitKat knockoffs, the Guardian reports. Nestle, which makes KitKats, has been fighting Cadbury (and then Mondelez, which ultimately bought Cadbury) in the courts for more than a decade on this issue. The BBC notes that Nestle first applied for trademark protection for the candy's shape in 2002, and it was granted that protection four years later. Cadbury's pushback began in 2007, and Wednesday's decision by the European Court of Justice essentially tells the EU trademark office it now has to "reconsider" its original decision. What that means, however, is that if the EU Intellectual Property Office finds, based on more recent evidence, that the KitKat bar's shape is recognizable in enough countries, it can retain the trademark protection, per Reuters. The brand name itself of "KitKat" is not being contested. (Atari accused Nestle of ripping off one of its popular video games in an ad for KitKat.)
response: The European Court of Justice has dismissed appeals by Nestle and Mondelez, ending a long-running legal battle over the shape of KitKat finger wafers. The court found that Nestle had failed to show that consumers in enough EU countries recognized the shape as distinctive, but also dismissed an appeal by Mondelez against some of the grounds for a lower EU court ruling in 2016. The case has implications for brands operating across the EU single market, where there are varying histories in national markets. The trademark agency could still take account of other evidence and preserve protection for KitKat's shape. In a separate dispute, Nestle objected to a trademark for the purple color used by Cadbury to wrap its Dairy Milk chocolate bars. </s>

answers: Dinosaurs may have been much more like modern birds than we knew—and not just because some had feathers. A new study suggests that mighty dinosaurs of yore didn't roar, contrary to every dinosaur movie you've ever seen. Instead, they made a decidedly less scary sound called a "closed-mouth vocalization." Think of a dove cooing or perhaps an ostrich doing this grunting thing. As the scientists explain in the journal Evolution, per UT News, the sound actually comes out of the neck area after air is pushed through an esophageal pouch. In fact, the animal's mouth is shut the whole time. Lots of birds do this today, and because birds descended from dinosaurs, scientists suspect they may have communicated in a similar way. The fossil record can't prove it, though the Washington Post notes that previous research meshes with the idea, including the belief that dinosaurs had air sacs instead of vocal chords. “A cool thing about this work is the demonstration that closed-mouth behavior evolved many times,” says the lead author. “That suggests it can emerge fairly easily and be incorporated into mating displays" among different types of animals. A co-author says the study gives the impression of "a very different Jurassic world. Not only were dinosaurs feathered, but they may have had bulging necks and made booming, closed-mouth sounds." But if so, the makers of Jurassic Park didn't get it all wrong: The hiss of the film's velociraptors came from a goose, per Vulture. (Scientists have grown chickens with dinosaur legs.)
response:
The studies found that T-Rex's iconic roar is likely a fiction created by Hollywood, and that dinosaurs may have vocalized more like birds. Researchers discovered this by studying modern bird species that produce low-pitched sounds with closed mouths and found that large-bodied dinosaurs may have had the same ability. This means that some dinosaurs may have cooed or made other low-pitched sounds instead of the iconic roar. Additionally, the study suggests that the capacity for closed-mouth vocalization was present in at least some extinct non-avian dinosaurs. It is likely that some dinosaurs made closed-mouthed vocalizations, perhaps during mating displays, but there is no direct fossil evidence to support this.

In another study, researchers found that most dinosaur species have yet to be discovered, and that much remains unknown about dinosaurs. The study also suggested that some dinosaurs may have mumbled or cooed with closed mouths, similar to birds.

The researchers used a statistical approach to analyze the distribution of closed-mouth vocalization among birds and other reptilian groups. They identified 52 out of 208 investigated bird species that use closed-mouth vocalization and found that only animals with a relatively large body size use this behavior.

In a related note, the study of dinosaur vocals is a topic of interest, and future research will integrate information from fossils, experimental physiology, gene expression, and sound modeling to understand the sounds produced by extinct early avian species and perhaps their dinosaur ancestors.</s>

answers: In an attempt to bury a relic of its past, Vanderbilt University announced Monday that it will pay more than $1 million to remove the word "Confederate" from one of its dorms, the Tennessean reports. Chancellor Nicholas S. Zeppos called the inscription on Confederate Memorial Hall "a reminder of racism, slavery and a very, very bloody Civil War." The Nashville university's efforts to change the name in 2002 were halted when the United Daughters of the Confederacy sued. The group’s $50,000 donation in 1933 helped build the dorm. A state appeals court ruled the building could be renamed Memorial Hall only after Vanderbilt gave the United Daughters back their money—$1.2 million in today’s dollars. The university has the cash, thanks to a raft of anonymous contributors who wanted the tie to America’s painful past broken for good. "It's a symbol that is, for many people, deeply offensive and painful," Zeppos told the Tennessean. "And to walk past it or to have to live in that space is really something that I just don't think is acceptable.” Yet tampering with Confederate imagery remains controversial, and a new state law makes it harder to do so, the AP reports. Efforts by Middle Tennessee State University in Murfreesboro to remove the name of Confederate Gen. Nathan Bedford Forrest from a building could face a tougher climb under the Tennessee Heritage Protection Act, which now requires a vote of two-thirds of the state’s Historical Commission rather than a simple majority.

The school will pay the equivalent of the gift made 83 years ago to relinquish the naming rights. The money has been pledged by anonymous donors. The university chooses to focus on "moving Vanderbilt forward" rather than on what projects the Daughters of the Confederacy will spend the funds on. answers: A classy move by a Florida cop is making headlines: Laurie Graber, an officer in Plantation, got the call for a particularly low-level crime—someone had ripped the engagement ring off the finger of an 87-year-old woman bedridden with Alzheimer's in a hospital, reports Fox News. answers: InterContinentalExchange Inc. has agreed to buy NYSE Euronext, the company that owns the New York Stock Exchange, for $8.2 billion, the two companies announced this morning. ICE, an Atlanta-based commodity exchange, says it intends to leave the NYSE's branding alone, and would explore an IPO for Euronext, spinning it off into a continental European entity, the Wall Street Journal reports. It will pay $33.12 a share for the elder exchange, or about a 37% premium on yesterday's close. While the 12-year-old company may lack the name recognition of the iconic NYSE, it's much larger in terms of market capitalization, at $9.3 billion to NYSE Euronext's $5.8 billion—a sign, the New York Times observes, of how completely commodity trading has outpaced stock trading in relevance.
response:
Two major news stories have emerged in the world of finance:

Firstly, the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE Euronext) is in talks to be acquired by IntercontinentalExchange (ICE) in an $8 billion deal that would create a powerful new player in the derivatives market. The deal would see NYSE Euronext, which has been struggling in the face of declining stock trading volumes, acquire ICE's commodities and derivatives trading platform, in a move that would give it a major presence in the fast-growing derivatives market. The merger is expected to be announced as soon as Thursday morning, and would create a company with a market value of over $30 billion.

Secondly, the New York Stock Exchange, which has been the cornerstone of American capitalism for 220 years, has agreed to be sold as part of an $8.2 billion takeover by IntercontinentalExchange Inc. The takeover would create a new company that would own 14 stock and futures exchanges and five clearing operations, doing more things in more places than any other rival. The deal would also mark the triumph of electronic trading over "open outcry" floor trading that long dominated financial markets.

Overall, these two news stories signal a major shake-up in the world of finance, with a focus on derivatives trading and electronic trading. The mergers and acquisitions in the industry are expected to continue, as companies seek to gain scale and cost savings through consolidation.</s>

answers: Apparently still smarting from some of Chris Rock's Oscars barbs, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences invited 683 people—many of them women and minorities—to join in an unprecedented move Wednesday, Reuters reports. The voting group behind the Oscars is largely old, white, and male and was lambasted this year with the hashtag #OscarsSoWhite after two years in a row of all-white acting nominees. In response, the academy is attempting to—as the AV Club puts it—" add seemingly goddamn everyone it had, for one reason or another, forgotten to invite into its membership.” The actors, directors, and others invited Wednesday include Idris Elba, Eva Mendes, Oscar Isaac, John Boyega, Ice Cube, Greta Gerqig, Michael B. answers: Scientists at UC Berkeley have made a major advancement in the field of mind reading, reconstructing YouTube videos based on brain scans from people who’d seen them. Researchers would put subjects into an MRI machine and track their brain activity as they viewed videos. Once they’d build a model of how a subject’s mind processed the video, “we could read brain activity for that subject and run it backward … to try to uncover what the viewer saw,” one study coauthor tells ABC News. Using the scans they were then able to reproduce the videos—though they’re blurry. “This is a major leap,” the co-author says. He thinks the technique could eventually be used to reconstruct dreams or memories, if it turns out the brain processes those things similarly to how it processes movies. “It’s our next line of research.” (More details on how the experiment worked, along with a video, at PC Magazine.)
response: Scientists from UC Berkeley have made a breakthrough in the field of brain imaging. They have been able to read brain activity and create a video of what a person is watching, even if the person is not aware of it. This technology has the potential to open up new avenues in the study of the brain and could potentially be used in detective work or court cases. Additionally, the technology could be used to help people who are paralyzed control their environment by imagining sequences of movements. However, there are ethical concerns regarding the use of this technology, as it could potentially be used to invade people's privacy and watch their memories. The study used brain activity recorded by an MRI machine to create a video of the subject's visual experience, and the results were published in the journal Current Biology. This technology has the potential to revolutionize the way we understand the brain and could lead to new treatments for paralysis and other neurological conditions. Further research is needed to fully understand the implications of this technology and to determine its potential uses.</s>

answers: We shouldn't be too worried about the sequester—after all, Congress doesn't exactly seem to be recoiling at the thought. Of course our lawmakers "might have to figure out how to put those plastic coffee pods in the machines themselves, but these people are not fools," he writes. "They will order out. In fact, House Republicans are positively excited about the sequester, writes Dana Milbank in the Washington Post, noting their agenda yesterday consisted only of renaming a California NASA research center. They're "pursuing a considered strategy of deliberate idleness," after finally realizing that doing nothing means they get "a 2.5% cut in all federal spending without coughing up a single dollar in tax increases. Politicians have lost their power to frighten me. I no longer believe the sky is falling. I have lived through America's past disasters, such as Vietnam, Watergate, and disco. It is supposed to scare us witless, but it is really no scarier than hearing the words, "I don't like the looks of that mole" or "Welcome to Carnival Cruise Lines." The sequester was designed to be so horrible that both Republicans and Democrats in Congress would recoil from it. All sorts of things will be cut under a sequester, including border security, airport security, Head Start, public housing support, NASA, special education, the FBI, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, and national defense. But do you know what does not get cut? The salaries of senators and representatives do not get cut under sequester. Congressional staffers face a 20% pay cut through furloughs, but members of Congress will continue to receive their six-figure salaries.

answers: Forget satellite images and aerial searches—the best way to find Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 may be with mathematical techniques dating back to the 18th century, the BBC reports. That's how Air France flight 447 was found in 2009, using "Bayesian statistics" to measure the probability of the plane being in one place or another. Named after Presbyterian minister and mathematician Thomas Bayes, the technique allowed experts to apply several factors to each point on a map: For example, what was the chance it crashed from mechanical failure? How far do planes tend to crash from their last known location? What was the chance that search teams missed debris in various locations? It's like picking a restaurant by balancing how full it is, what your favorite restaurant-review website says, and so on—except that experts hunting for Airbus A330 did that for each point where plane may have crashed in the Atlantic, Five Thirty-Eight notes. It was so hard that the US team of statisticians invited by France gave up, until they de-emphasized one statistic: that a plane's black box emits a signal after a crash 90% of the time. They changed their findings, and presto, the plane was found. Bayesian techniques have helped people find World War II U-boats, men overboard, and sunken treasure, but there's no evidence that Malaysia is employing them now. "I suspect that they just guess, like professional baseball managers used to do before Moneyball," says a biostatistician.
response: News about the Malaysian Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared on March 8, 2014, is provided. The latest search efforts utilize Bayesian statistics to refine and focus the hunt for the plane. The use of Bayesian inference to update probabilities and assist in the search is explained, with examples from other searches, such as the search for Air France Flight 447. The challenges in finding basic information about which areas have already been searched, subjective judgment, and the possibility that an earlier search covered an area including the wreckage site but missed it. The probability of the plane being found in locations that had already been searched is lowered. The case of Air France Flight 447, where the Bayesian approach helped find the wreckage, is discussed. Keller and her team from Metron Inc in Virginia relied on Bayesian statistics to work out the most likely location of the plane. The team split up the search area into a grid, applied to each cell a figure representing the probability that the plane would be found there. The case of the Air France plane, where the Bayesian approach helped find the wreckage, is discussed. The Metron statisticians adapted their model to the possible scenario of neither the black box nor the voice recorder sending a signal. The team returned to the scene to look and found the plane. The mystery of the crash was solved. The Bayesian approach allows for the consideration of all the data, including uncertainties, and the combination of views that contradict each other. It also allows for the update of the body of knowledge at any time, making it a useful tool in search efforts.</s>

answers: A strong smell outside a California supermarket turned out to be someone who had decomposed in one of the store's entrance columns, ABC 7 reports. Police were called Saturday to the WinCo Foods in Lancaster after a plumber, told it was likely a septic problem, helped knock brick from the column and saw a shoe and a leg inside. He crashed the vehicle, ran away from deputies, and got into the supermarket. The man "ran up the steps where the managers [are]," an eyewitness tells CBS Los Angeles. "And somehow he got on the roof. Last I heard, he got away." From up there, he could have reached the store fascia and descended into the column. answers: A New Orleans judge officially approved Robert Durst's February plea deal on a gun charge and sentenced him to seven years in prison on Wednesday, Reuters reports. Real estate heir Robert Durst was sentenced to seven years in prison for a federal gun crime and agreed to be transferred to California, where he will face a murder charge in the 2000 death of his friend Susan Berman. Durst has pleaded guilty to the gun charge and maintained his innocence in Berman's death. answers: The Republican-led House Benghazi committee released its final report Tuesday after two years of investigations. answers: A former police bloodhound handler told a court on Monday that during the search for UVa student Hannah Graham, the animal detected her scent outside the car and apartment of suspect Jesse Matthew—and the scent of "fear and adrenaline" where she was allegedly attacked. answers: A white-collar crook is facing extra prison time for having his son shoot him in the legs with a 20-gauge shotgun, the BBC reports. Shannon Egeland, 43, was already facing 10 years for taking part in a vast mortgage-fraud scheme when he had his 17-year-old son shoot him by a road in Caldwell, Idaho, in an attempt to avoid prison. "The psychological and emotional destruction defendant caused this minor child is unimaginable," US attorney Scott Bradford wrote in a sentencing memo. Back in 2009, Egeland was co-owner of an Oregon development company that defrauded banks out of $20 million in loans that he and a partner used to fund a lavish lifestyle. Facing prison, Egeland took out disability insurance and had his son aim for his legs. Egeland told police he'd been attacked after stopping to assist a pregnant driver, but investigators got suspicious when his pricey BMW, his wallet, and his cellphone weren't taken, the Idaho Statesman reports. Then they learned about his recent insurance, and the whole thing unravelled. Now Egeland is facing an extra 3 years and 10 months for his roadside scheme and had his leg amputated from the shotgun blast. Bradford called him a "self-absorbed, opportunistic narcissist," the Oregonian reports, but Egeland—who is now on three medications for mental health—has cast his own judgment. "What bothers me the most is my son—the pain is on him,'' he says. "If I could take it all back, I would, but I can't. That will haunt me the rest of my life.''
response:
Shannon Egeland, a convicted white-collar criminal, has had his prison sentence extended to 13 years after he made his teenage son shoot him in the legs in a failed attempt to delay his prison sentence. Egeland had previously been sentenced to 10 years in prison for his role in a mortgage fraud scheme, and he applied for disability insurance a week before staging the shooting. Prosecutors described him as a "menace to society" and a "self-absorbed, opportunistic narcissist" who recklessly manipulated his son. Egeland's defense lawyer argued that he is already facing a lengthy sentence and urged the judge to consider mental health treatment and counseling while in prison. The judge ordered Egeland to pay $90,011 in child support and to submit to a new mental health evaluation when he is released from custody.

In another development, Egeland's plot to delay his prison sentence by staging a shooting backfired, and he lost his left leg in the process. He is now standing on a prosthetic limb and facing an additional three years and 10 months in jail. Egeland's son was not charged in the incident, but the assistant US attorney described the shooting as a "perfect storm" of medical and mental health issues, financial difficulties, and the "anxiety of having to report for a 10-year federal prison sentence." The prosecutor also noted that the psychological and emotional destruction caused to the minor child is unimaginable. The judge urged Egeland to get mental health treatment and counseling while in prison and to submit to a new mental health evaluation when he is released.</s>

answers: The Tesla Model X that slammed into a highway barrier in California last week and killed the 38-year-old Apple engineer at the wheel had been on autopilot at the time of the crash, Tesla confirms in a blog post. But the company says driver Walter Huang "received several visual and one audible hands-on warning earlier in the drive," adding that "the driver’s hands were not detected on the wheel for six seconds prior to the collision." Tesla also laid some blame on state highway officials, asserting that "the reason this crash was so severe is because the crash attenuator, a highway safety barrier which is designed to reduce the impact into a concrete lane divider, had been crushed in a prior accident without being replaced." The fact that the vehicle was on autopilot is likely to be controversial because, as ABC News notes, driver Huang had reportedly been concerned about it. His brother told KGO that Huang had brought his Model X back to the dealership complaining that when he used the feature, the car kept swerving toward the very same barrier that it eventually struck in the fatal collision. The NTSB is investigating the crash, including the fire that broke out after the collision. The accident follows another in Arizona in which a self-driving Uber struck and killed a pedestrian.
response:
There were three news passages provided. Below is a summary of all the news.

Passage 1:
Tesla released a statement regarding the fatal crash that occurred last week, confirming that the vehicle was engaged in Autopilot mode at the time of the accident. According to Tesla, the driver had received several visual and audible warnings before the collision, but the driver's hands were not detected on the wheel for six seconds prior to the collision. The reason for the severity of the accident was attributed to the crash attenuator, which had been damaged in a prior accident without being replaced.

Passage 2:
A 38-year-old man was killed in a Tesla crash on the 101 Highway near Mountain View, California. The family of the victim, Walter Huang, reported that he had complained about the vehicle's Autopilot system veering towards the same barrier multiple times before the accident. An investigation is ongoing, and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has recovered two modules from the vehicle.

Passage 3:
Tesla stated that the Autopilot system was engaged with the adaptive cruise control follow-distance set to minimum in the moments before the collision. The driver had received several visual and audible warnings, but the driver's hands were not detected on the wheel for six seconds prior to the collision. The reason for the severity of the accident was attributed to the damaged crash attenuator, which had not been replaced after a previous accident. The family of the victim reported that he had complained about the vehicle's Autopilot system veering towards the same barrier multiple times before the accident.

In summary, a fatal crash occurred last week involving a Tesla that was in Autopilot mode, resulting in the death of the driver. The family of the victim reported that he had complained about the Autopilot system veering towards the same barrier multiple times before the accident, and an investigation is ongoing.</s>

answers: After Robin Williams' sudden death, the tributes are rolling in, with many recalling a comic genius grappling with private challenges. A sampling: When it comes to comedy, "there wasn't a faster brain on the planet," writes Tony Hicks in the Contra Costa Times. We'll be hearing "a litany of tributes about one of the great comedians who ever lived. Much of it will be some of the same adjectives used when any great performer dies—especially before their time. But in Williams' case, most of it will be true." Early in his career, "it was clear that Mr. Williams was one of the most explosively, exhaustingly, prodigiously verbal comedians who ever lived," AO Scott writes in the New York Times. And beyond that, "his essential persona as an entertainer combined neediness and generosity, intelligence and kindness, in ways that were charming and often unexpectedly moving." Williams may have gotten his start long before Aladdin, but he gave a "generous and humble" gift to the millennial generation, writes Daniel D'Addario at Salon. "Williams will be remembered for his edgy comedy and for dramatic turns, but for people my age, Williams was our childhood," from Mrs. Doubtfire to Jumanji to Flubber. In the Los Angeles Times, Kenneth Turan recalls a moment when, facing an onslaught of photographers, Williams asked him—in the voice of a fly from a 1950s sci-fi flick—to "help me, Ken. Help me." The experience stuck with him and seems particularly resonant today, he writes.
response:
Robin Williams, a beloved actor and comedian, passed away at the age of 63. News passages remember him for his diverse filmography, from "Hook" to "Jumanji," and his ability to make people laugh. Williams was known for his improvisational skills and his ability to connect with children. He won an Oscar for his role in "Good Will Hunting" and was praised for his performances in "Mrs. Doubtfire" and "Flubber." Despite his success, Williams struggled with adult dramas and disappeared from leading-man roles. He later rebooted his career in children's movies. His legacy is measured by the imprints his movies left on rec-room carpets. Williams' cause of death was asphyxia from an apparent suicide. Fate threw the author in Williams' path multiple times, and they remembered his stand-up comedy routines and his ability to make lightning-fast comic connections.

Robin Williams died at 63 due to asphyxia from an apparent suicide. He left behind a legacy of diverse filmography, improvisational skills, and the ability to connect with children. His performances in "Mrs. Doubtfire" and "Flubber" were particularly noteworthy, and his success in children's movies later in his career is a testament to his versatility as an actor.</s>

answers: Police in the country's smallest state capital are investigating something that hasn't happened there in living memory: a murder. Police in Vermont say they have issued an arrest warrant for 29-year-old Jayveon Caballero, who is accused of fatally shooting Markus Austin in Montpelier early Sunday after an altercation, the Times Argus reports. Witnesses told investigators that Austin, 33, assaulted Caballero’s girlfriend, Desiree Cary, during the altercation outside a bar in the nearby city of Barre early Sunday. Police say Caballero later confronted Austin outside his apartment and shot him dead. The body was found in the parking lot of Austin's apartment complex. A Vermont State Police spokesman says Caballero, who knew Austin before the shooting, fled the town and probably the state after the shooting, WCAX reports. The police spokesman says Caballero is believed to have boarded a Greyhound bus bound for New York City on Sunday morning, which made numerous stops in other states along the way. Later Sunday, Cary, 22, was arrested on apparently unrelated charges of selling heroin and crack cocaine. With around 7,500 residents, Montpelier has the smallest population of any state capital, the AP notes. Police Chief Anthony Facos says this is the city's first murder since a woman shot her husband in the 1920s.
response:
A murder investigation is ongoing in Montpelier, Vermont, after a former Vermont Frost Heaves basketball player was shot and killed outside an apartment complex. Police have issued an arrest warrant for Jayveon Caballero, 29, of Barre, for second-degree murder. Caballero is believed to have boarded a bus on Sunday in White River Junction, and police are unsure if he got off at an intermediate stop. The victim, 33-year-old Markus Austin, was shot outside his apartment after an altercation outside Gustos bar in Barre. Caballero's girlfriend, Desiree Cary, was arrested on drug charges. The shooting is the first murder in Montpelier in almost a century.

Police are asking for anyone with information about Caballero's location to contact them. The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are reaching out to other states for help. The victim, Austin, was a former member of the Vermont Frost Heaves, a now-dissolved team in the American Basketball Association.</s>

answers: Look up at the sky on Jan. 31 and you may witness a sight unseen for 150 years. For the first time since 1866, a total lunar eclipse will occur with the blue moon, or second full moon of the month, which—like the one visible on New Year's Day—will also be a supermoon. Got all that? When the moon is at or near the closest point to Earth in its orbit (aka, a supermoon), it appears 14% bigger and 30% brighter than full moons that occur at the farthest point in the moon's orbit, though the moon will lose brightness as it enters Earth's shadow, according to NASA. Because of the way Earth's atmosphere bends light, the eclipsed moon will take on a reddish hue, something often referred to as a blood moon, making this rare celestial event "a super blue blood moon eclipse," according to the Miami Herald. The next blue moon eclipse won't occur until 2028. The eclipse will last for 3.5 hours, with the total eclipse stretching for 77 minutes, reports Sky & Telescope. Those along the Pacific Rim from Alaska and northwestern Canada to central and eastern Asia, Indonesia, New Zealand, and Australia will get the best view of totality during the middle of the night. However, partial phases of the eclipse should be visible under a clear sky in central North America, western Asia, India, the Middle East and eastern Europe, per Space.com. North American viewers should look up as the moon sets on the morning of Jan. 31, while those on the opposite side of the world should see a partial eclipse as the moon rises. Not in an ideal viewing area? The Virtual Telescope plans to livestream the total eclipse from Australia, which you can watch here, per Quartz. (Bogus glasses damaged a solar eclipse viewer's eyes.)
response:
There will be a total lunar eclipse on January 31, 2018, which is also a Blue Moon. The eclipse will be visible in the Pacific Ocean and parts of Asia, Australia, and the Americas. The Virtual Telescope Project will provide a live, online session of the event. The supermoon will rise over Rome on January 31, and the lunar eclipse will begin at 11:48 am UTC. The Virtual Telescope Project will also provide a livestream of the eclipse from Australia. The best time to see the supermoon is after moonrise and before sunrise. The lunar eclipse will be visible from eastern Asia across the Pacific to western North America. The moon will appear bigger and brighter during the eclipse due to the moon illusion effect. The Virtual Telescope Project provides a livestream of the event, and you can also take pictures of the supermoon and lunar eclipse with a smartphone or DSLR. You do not need special glasses to watch the supermoon or lunar eclipse.

This summary captures all the essential information from the three passages, including the date and time of the lunar eclipse, the visibility of the event, and how to view and photograph it. Additionally, it highlights the uniqueness of the event, with the combination of a Blue Moon, supermoon, and total lunar eclipse occurring for the first time in nearly 152 years.</s>

answers: America's ambassador to Syria visited one of the cities worst-hit by the crackdown against anti-government protesters yesterday, reports CNN. Robert Ford went to the city of Hama "to make absolutely clear with his physical presence that we stand with those Syrians who are expressing their right to speak for change," an embassy spokeswoman says. An estimated 500,000 people joined an anti-government rally in the city last Friday. The Syrian government accused Ford of going to the city without authorization, saying the visit is "clear evidence of the US involvement in the ongoing events in Syria and its bids to aggravate the situations which destabilize Syria.'' An embassy spokeswoman says the Syrian government was told a delegation would be visiting Hama, although no Syrian "handlers" were taken and officials weren't informed about the ambassador's presence. The city has been a symbol of opposition since 1982, when a crackdown ordered by the present Syrian leader's father killed around 20,000 people, al-Jazeera notes.
response:
US Ambassador Robert Ford visited Hama, Syria, to show support for protesters, despite the Syrian government's objections. Ford met with over a dozen residents and visited a hospital treating wounded protesters. The Syrian government accused the US of "interfering" in its affairs, and the US state department replied that the ambassador's presence was to show support for the right of Syrians to express themselves peacefully. Protests across Syria, including in Homs and Damascus, resulted in the deaths of at least 13 protesters, with reports of snipers from "armed gangs" being responsible. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that over 500,000 protesters flooded the city of Hama, making it the largest protest yet against the government. The French ambassador also showed support in Hama. The Syrian government accused the US of "interfering" in its affairs, and the US state department replied that the ambassador's presence was to show support for the right of Syrians to express themselves peacefully. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that over 500,000 protesters flooded the city of Hama, making it the largest protest yet against the government.

Overall, the news highlights the ongoing unrest and violence in Syria, with protesters continuing to demand change and the government responding with force. The US and French ambassadors' visits to Hama are seen as a show of support for the protesters, while the Syrian government accuses the US of interfering in its affairs. The deaths of at least 13 protesters and the displacement of an estimated 1,000 people from Hama further highlight the escalating situation in the country.</s>

answers: The FBI is reportedly investigating a sophisticated—but unsuccessful—attempt to hack into the Democratic National Committee's voter database. The DNC learned of the attempt on Tuesday, CNN reports. The attack, which was detected by a cloud service provider and a security research company, involved a fake login page intended to gather usernames and passwords for a service called Votebuilder, which hosts the DNC's voter database. It's a method called "spearphishing," according to the New York Times. "It was very convincing," Mike Murray of the cybersecurity firm Lookout tells CNN, adding that it would be tough to tell the real page from the fake one, even if they were side-by-side. The fake login page was ultimately removed by the cloud hosting company DigitalOcean. The company's chief security officer says the threat was identified before the attack was launched. "We see no evidence that any sensitive data was stolen," he says. A DNC official tells the Times that it is not clear who the hackers were in this case. But, the paper recalls, a 2016 hack of the DNC was ultimately traced to Russia. This latest attempt, DNC Chief Security Officer Bob Lord tells the Times, "is further proof that there are constant threats as we head into midterm elections and we must remain vigilant in order to prevent future attacks." Earlier this week, Microsoft reported that it had uncovered new Russian hacking attempts targeting conservative organizations in the US.
response: The Democratic National Committee (DNC) has reported an attempt to hack into its voter database, with the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) investigating the incident. The DNC believes the attempt was a sophisticated phishing test, but Microsoft has detected Russian intelligence hackers targeting the Senate and conservative think tanks. Facebook has also identified disinformation efforts targeting people around the world. The incident highlights the ongoing threats to midterm elections, with the cyber age changing elections forever and making systems vulnerable to manipulation. Efforts to breach think tanks and continued influence operations by Russia and others using social media underscore the need for vigilance to prevent future attacks. The DNC and two security companies involved in detecting the operation believe they thwarted a potential attack, but the incident serves as a reminder of the constant threats to election security.</s>

answers: Another fatality in the Boston bombings has been identified: The family of 29-year-old Krystle Campbell says she was killed as she and a friend were cheering on another friend who was racing, reports WCVB. "This is just a waste," says her mother. “Everyone that knew her loved her. She was always smiling. You couldn’t ask for a better daughter. She was the best.” Campbell was a restaurant manager, reports the Boston Herald, which notes an especially wrenching detail: Her father was initially told she was alive, but when he got to the ICU, he realized it was his daughter's friend who had survived. Campbell is the second of the three people killed to be identified. The first was 8-year-old Martin Richard, and his father, Bill, released a statement today thanking supporters and asking for privacy, reports WBZ. "My dear son Martin has died from injuries sustained in the attack on Boston. My wife and daughter are both recovering from serious injuries. We thank our family and friends, those we know and those we have never met, for their thoughts and prayers. I ask that you continue to pray for my family as we remember Martin. We also ask for your patience and for privacy as we work to simultaneously grieve and recover. Thank you." The third victim was a grad student at Boston University, but the person's identity is being withheld until the family says it's OK to release, reports USA Today.
response:
The Boston Marathon bombings resulted in the deaths of three people, including an 8-year-old boy, and injured hundreds more. The bombings took place near the finish line of the marathon on Monday afternoon. The victim's names have been identified as Martin Richard, Krystle Campbell, and a Chinese graduate student from Boston University. The city of Boston has been left grappling with the painful process of identifying its dead, a strong police presence on its streets, and a firm resolve to heal and move forward.

The investigation into the bombings is ongoing, with police promising "significantly enhanced" security at bus and train stations and airports. The mayor of Boston, Thomas Menino, has vowed that the city will not be intimidated by terror.

In the aftermath of the bombings, the Salvation Army has mobilized four mobile kitchens and more than 30 people to provide food, drinks, and emotional and spiritual care. The First Corps of Cadets Armory in downtown Boston has become a staging area for runners looking for their gear bags, trying to find lost phones and passports, or trying to make travel arrangements.

The bombings have received words of encouragement and solidarity from across the nation and around the world, including from President Obama and Pope Francis. The city of Boston has come together to support the victims and their families, with a strong sense of community and resilience in the face of tragedy.</s>

answers: There are more obese or overweight people in the world today than there were people of any weight in 1935, the most comprehensive look at worldwide obesity in decades warns. The 188-country study found that there are 2.1 billion overweight or obese people in the world, making up around 30% of the world's population, up from 20% in 1980, USA Today reports. Not a single country has recorded a decline in obesity over the last 30 years. "We hoped there would be some examples of success that you could latch onto," a study co-author says. "But there's a complete lack of success stories in bringing down obesity." The study published in British medical journal the Lancet found that the Middle East and north Africa had seen the biggest weight gains, though the US still has the largest number of obese people, with 87 million of the world's 671 million obese people, reports Reuters. Other countries, however, have even higher obesity rates, including Tonga, where more than 50% of all adults are obese. "Two-thirds of the obese population actually resides in developing countries," says one of the researchers; they warn that obesity rates are rising among rich and poor countries, men and women, and adults and children alike.
response:
According to the two passages, obesity is a growing global problem that affects both developed and developing countries. The most recent research shows that obesity has become a significant public health issue, with nearly 30% of the world's population being overweight or obese. 

The USA leads the world in obesity, but other countries like Tonga, Kuwait, and Kiribati have even higher obesity rates. Obesity co-exists with pockets of hunger in many countries, and the availability of cheap, fatty, sugary, salty, high-calorie "junk food" and the rise of sedentary lifestyles are contributing factors.  

Obesity is a complex problem with significant health implications, including heart disease, stroke, diabetes, arthritis, and certain cancers. According to the World Health Organization, chronic complications of weight kill about 3.4 million adults annually. 

The most comprehensive assessment to date of one of the pressing public health dilemmas of our time shows that population-wide weight gains and income gains generally go hand in hand around the world. Obesity is now gripping people of all ages, incomes, and regions, with no country succeeding in cutting its obesity rate. 

Young people are also being affected, with obesity rising nearly 50% in children and adolescents worldwide. The study concludes that obesity is not just a cosmetic issue but a main risk factor for morbidity and mortality, and it is essential to address this issue to improve public health.</s>

answers: It's been a year since Katie Holmes filed for divorce from Tom Cruise, and apparently Cruise is feeling sentimental. Even so, "It won't have been an over the top letter—it has been a year and I'm sure Tom will have been aware that Katie wouldn't be interested in running straight back into his arms." answers: The investigation into the mysterious deaths of a billionaire and his wife is now being led by homicide detectives, police say—suggesting the deaths of Barry and Honey Sherman were either murder-suicide or a double murder. Police, who have described the deaths as "suspicious," revealed Sunday that the cause of death for both Shermans was "ligature neck compression," a form of strangulation, the CBC reports. Sources have told the media that the couple were found hanging near an indoor pool in the basement of their Toronto mansion. Police say they haven't found any sign of forced entry, or a note that could explain what happened to 75-year-old pharmaceutical tycoon Barry Sherman and his 70-year-old wife, both renowned philanthropists. The couple's four children have rejected what they say are "rumors" that the deaths are being investigated as a murder-suicide, and many of the influential couple's friends agree. "There is absolutely zero debate in my mind, this was a double homicide," says Canadian Sen. Linda Frum, a longtime friend of the couple, per the New York Times. The Globe and Mail reports that just days before the bodies were found, Honey Sherman was enthusiastically making plans for their annual trip to Florida, emailing friends that she would be traveling to the state on Dec. 18 and Barry Sherman would join her a week later. The couple also sent out invitations last week to a dinner party at their winter home in Palm Beach.
response:
On December 15, 2022, billionaire Barry Sherman, the founder of Apotex Inc., and his wife Honey were found dead in their Toronto mansion, with police later confirming that their deaths were "suspicious" and due to "ligature neck compression," a term typically used to describe strangulation. The couple was known for their philanthropy and high social standing, with friends and colleagues describing them as kind and generous. However, police have not ruled out the possibility of a murder-suicide, despite the family's denial of any such theory.

The couple had listed their home for sale for $7 million, and their real estate agent had discovered the bodies. Police have not identified any suspects or indicated any motive for the deaths. The couple's net worth was estimated at $4.77 billion, making Barry Sherman the 15th richest person in Canada.

The investigation is ongoing, with homicide detectives taking over the case. Friends and colleagues of the couple have expressed shock and disbelief at the news, and tributes have poured in for the couple's philanthropic work and contributions to the community.

Overall, the news passage describes the sudden and mysterious deaths of a wealthy and influential couple, with the investigation ongoing and the possibility of a murder-suicide still under consideration.</s>

answers: The final round of voting began in Egypt today, and it looks like the Muslim Brotherhood could walk off with a controlling majority of seats in Parliament's lower house. The Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party, the country's mainstream Islamist party, had already won a high percentage of the seats awarded in the first and second rounds of voting. Two of the nine provinces voting today are Brotherhood strongholds, where some of the party's most well-known candidates are running, the New York Times reports. A plurality, not a majority, was originally predicted for the Freedom and Justice Party. A majority would allow the party to govern alone, but the Brotherhood has repeatedly said it plans to form a coalition government, and has aligned itself with more liberal parties rather than the ultraconservative Salafis, who are in second place with up to 25% of the seats so far. Also today, prosecutors began presenting their case against former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Bloomberg notes. His trial resumed last week after a two-month break; state TV today showed Mubarak being carried to and from the courtroom on a gurney. "He deserves an end of humiliation and indignity," said the chief prosecutor, according to the AP.
response:
In Egypt, the third and final round of voting in the parliamentary election is underway, with the Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party expected to consolidate its lead. The trial of former President Hosni Mubarak has resumed, with the prosecution accusing him of imposing "tyrannical rule" and devoting the last 10 years of his three decades in power to ensure his son's succession. Mubarak and his two sons, including his one-time heir apparent Gamal, face charges of complicity in the killing of more than 800 protesters in the crackdown on a popular uprising that forced him out of office on Feb. 11. The trial has been bogged down in procedural matters, with lawyers representing the victims demanding that the presiding judge be removed. The prosecution has accused Mubarak of corruption and attempting to pass power to his son, and has called for the harshest penalty if he is convicted.

In related news, the Egyptian military has announced that it will retain power after the elections and will not cede authority to the new parliament until a new president is elected. The military has also set the date for the first session of the new parliament, which is expected to be dominated by Islamist groups.

Overall, the news highlights the ongoing political and legal developments in Egypt as the country continues to transition to a new era of governance. The trials of former President Mubarak and his sons, as well as the ongoing power struggles between Islamist groups and the military, are expected to continue to be major focal points in the coming months.</s>

answers: Police in Vermont say a car ended up almost vertical when the driver swerved quickly in response to her GPS ordering her to "turn around." The car was suspended almost vertically on guide wires attached to a utility pole (see a photo here) in Mendon on Wednesday night, reports the AP. Police say 30-year-old Nabila Altahan of Dorchester, Mass., was headed west on US Route 4 when she passed her intended destination and reacted quickly to the instructions, leaving the road at a significant enough speed to propel the vehicle up the wires. She wasn't injured. (This driver followed her GPS into a lake.)
response: A bizarre accident occurred in Mendon, Vermont, when a driver reacted too quickly to a GPS unit's instructions, causing her car to become suspended from a telephone guy wire. The incident happened around 8 p.m. on Wednesday evening, when Nabila Altahan, the driver of a Toyota Corolla, was traveling westbound on Route 4. The GPS device gave sudden directions to turn around, as the car had passed its intended destination, and Altahan reacted quickly to the directions, leaving the road and getting the car stuck on the guy wire. The driver and her passenger were not injured, and State Police and Rutland City Fire Department responded to the scene. A witness at a nearby miniature golf course saw the driver jump out of the car as it was suspended from the pole.</s>
